__data__.text: José Calvo Sotelo was a prominent figure in the anti-Republican Right wing, particularly after the failure of Gil-Robles' "possibilist policy" in the 1936 elections. He was known for his anti-democratic views and had expressed his intention to overthrow the parliament and end universal suffrage. During the campaigns for the general elections in 1933 and 1936, he repeatedly stated his goal of making these the last elections with universal suffrage for many years. His ideology was in opposition to the Republic and he saw the elections as a means to bring about its end.

In the 1936 election campaign, Calvo Sotelo insisted on making these elections the final ones with universal suffrage, arguing that frequent elections in a country's existence, tradition, and fundamental institutions cannot lead to prosperity. He opposed the "liberal democratic State" and advocated for a "corporative and authoritarian State" instead. Calvo Sotelo's anti-Republican stance was well-known, and the Republican Left deputy, Mariano Ansó, described him as the regime's most prominent adversary.

In the 1936 election campaign, Calvo Sotelo, a prominent adversary of the Republic, firmly opposed the "liberal democratic State" and advocated for a "corporative and authoritarian State." He despised the Republic from its inception and never reconciled with it. In fact, he was involved in the coup conspiracy of 1936, even offering to serve under General Mola in the planned uprising. Many monarchists believed that he would be a leading figure in the new regime after the Republic's overthrow.

Pedro Sainz Rodríguez and Eduardo Aunós, monarchists against the Republic, saw Calvo Sotelo as the key figure to lead a legal transformation of Spain after the anticipated overthrow of the Republic. Both had been ministers in the Primo de Rivera Dictatorship. Calvo Sotelo's speeches in the Cortes, similar to those of CEDA leader José María Gil-Robles, were met with strong disdain and aggression from most Popular Front deputies.

In his April 15 speech, Calvo Sotelo presented a list of violent incidents in Spain since the elections, detailing deaths, injuries, and damaged religious buildings. His comments were met with hostility from left-wing deputies, who accused him of instigating Falangist attacks and brought up the repression in Asturias. They interrupted him with shouts and personal attacks, with some even threatening to bring "useless" individuals from Asturias to the Cortes. The confrontational atmosphere persisted in subsequent sessions.

In response to Calvo Sotelo's statement that the violence has been ongoing for an extended period, a deputy shouted back, expressing that it will continue. During subsequent sessions, deputies repeatedly interrupted Calvo Sotelo with personal attacks and threats. For example, Margarita Nelken declared that executioners have no right to speak, and Bruno Alonso González challenged him to take their disagreement to the streets. The exchanges were often hostile, with deputies making personal insults and threats towards Calvo Sotelo.

Following Calvo Sotelo's assertion that the Government is strongly opposed to fascism, a deputy (Casares Quiroga) labels him a pimp, and another deputy (Alonso González) hurls personal insults at him. The president of the Cortes intervenes, and Alonso González is expelled from the Chamber. During the June 16 session, Calvo Sotelo speaks about the chaos and disorder in Spain and advocates for an authoritarian and corporative State, identifying himself as a Fascist. His statement is met with frequent interruptions and skepticism from the deputies.

In response to Calvo Sotelo's advocacy for a fascist, authoritarian state and his appeal to the military for intervention, a deputy remarks "What a novelty!", and Calvo Sotelo takes responsibility for any future coup attempts. This prompts a rebuke from President Santiago Casares Quiroga, who holds Calvo Sotelo accountable for any potential uprisings. Calvo Sotelo accepts this responsibility, characterizing Casares Quiroga as quick to make threats.

In the final Cortes session before the civil war, President Santiago Casares Quiroga criticizes Calvo Sotelo for encouraging a coup and compares him to Kerenski and Karoly. This leads to a heated exchange where Calvo Sotelo accepts responsibility for any uprisings and challenges Quiroga. The session is marked by disruptions, and a notable threat is made by Socialist deputy Ángel Galarza towards monarchist leader Calvo Sotelo. This tension highlights the conflict and instability present in the lead-up to the civil war.

In the Cortes session, President Santiago Casares Quiroga criticizes Calvo Sotelo's support for fascism, leading to a heated exchange where Calvo Sotelo takes responsibility for any uprisings and challenges Quiroga. Socialist deputy Ángel Galarza threatens monarchist leader Calvo Sotelo due to his past support for the dictatorship, highlighting the intense conflict and instability before the civil war. Galarza's words were not recorded in the Journal of Sessions but were reported by a journalist, expressing his surprise that Calvo Sotelo, who participated in the dictatorship, now advocates for justice independence while his party and other socialist groups oppose personal violence.

In the Cortes session, a conflict arises as Galarza threatens Calvo Sotelo due to his past support for the dictatorship, while Calvo Sotelo advocates for justice independence and permits violence against those who seek power through violence and want to take left-wing party members to concentration camps. This leads to heated exchanges, with Galarza's words not recorded in the Journal of Sessions. The President of the Cortes, Diego Martínez Barrio, intervenes to denounce violence and disallow its advocacy in Parliament, while Galarza submits to the Presidency's decision out of respect. This event showcases the intense political conflict and instability in Spain before the civil war.

Galarza submits to the Presidency's decision to not condone violence, but expresses that the public will still be aware of his stance through other means. Some historians argue that Calvo Sotelo and Gil-Robles' speeches in the Cortes, which were critical and negative about the violence in the streets, were part of a right-wing campaign to justify an upcoming coup and garner support through fear-mongering and catastrophizing discourse spread by like-minded press. This illustrates the political tension and instability in Spain prior to the civil war.

Eduardo González Calleja strongly suggests that the Spanish Civil War was essentially declared in Parliament before it even began in the streets, with Calvo Sotelo playing a significant role through his provocative stance. This view is echoed by José Luis Martín Ramos, who highlights a quote from Calvo Sotelo's speech that emphasizes the perceived failure of the democratic regime and the Constitution of 1931 to maintain economic and social order. This reflects the intense political tension and instability in Spain leading up to the civil war.

Eduardo González Calleja, José Luis Martín Ramos, Julio Aróstegui, and Paul Preston all agree that the Spanish Civil War was significantly influenced by the political climate and instability preceding it. A key figure in this context is Calvo Sotelo, who openly criticized the democratic regime and Constitution of 1931, claiming they caused economic and social disorder. Sotelo's repeated calls for the army's intervention and his self-proclaimed enmity towards the Republic's democracy led Italian historian Gabriele Ranzato to hold him responsible for the escalating violence in the country. Sotelo's strong anti-democratic stance and resulting hostility make him a significant figure in the lead-up to the civil war. Despite feeling threatened, Sotelo played a crucial role in the political tension and instability that characterized Spain before the war.

In the time leading up to the Spanish Civil War, Calvo Sotelo, a prominent critic of the democratic regime and Constitution of 1931, was seen as a significant figure due to his anti-democratic stance and hostility towards the Republic's democracy. Sotelo felt threatened and anticipated an attack on his life, even going as far as to sleep away from home and distrust his police escorts. His friends shared this concern and one of them gifted him an armored car in early July for his protection. Sotelo's fears were a reflection of the political tension and instability that plagued Spain before the war.

In the period preceding the Spanish Civil War, both Calvo Sotelo and Lieutenant José del Castillo felt endangered due to the political turmoil. Sotelo, an opponent of the democratic regime, received an armored car as a gift for protection, and three days before his assassination, they tested it in Parque del Buen Retiro. Meanwhile, Lieutenant Castillo, recognized for his Socialist ties and training, also feared for his life, as his name appeared on a UME list of Socialist soldiers marked for death, with Captain Carlos Faraudo being the primary target and Castillo as the second. After Faraudo's assassination by Falangist gunmen, Artillery Captain Urbano Orad de la Torre suspected UME's involvement and warned them that if another attack occurred, they would retaliate against a politician instead of an Army officer.

In the lead-up to the Spanish Civil War, both Calvo Sotelo and Lieutenant José del Castillo were in danger due to political unrest. Sotelo, an adversary of the democratic regime, received an armored car for protection, while Lieutenant Castillo, known for his Socialist connections and training, feared for his life as his name was on a UME list of Socialist soldiers targeted for death.

Following the assassination of Captain Faraudo by Falangist gunmen, Artillery Captain Urbano Orad de la Torre suspected UME's involvement and warned that if another attack happened, they would retaliate against a politician instead of an Army officer. At Faraudo's funeral, Lieutenant Colonel Julio Mangada, a close friend of Faraudo's, urged those present to demand the government take stronger action against fascist and reactionary provocations, threatening retaliation if they didn't. Civil Guard Captain Fernando Condés, who would later lead the group that assassinated Calvo Sotelo, was also present and agreed with the need for revenge against right-wing leaders.

In the lead-up to the Spanish Civil War, two months before the assassination of Calvo Sotelo, Lieutenant José del Castillo, a well-known Socialist and UMRA member, was killed by right-wing extremists. The murder was part of a series of attacks and counterattacks. Castillo's death caused great distress among his fellow guards at the Pontejos Barracks, particularly Captain Eduardo Cuevas de la Peña and Lieutenant Alfonso Barbeta, who were determined to retaliate. The identity of the assailants remains unclear, but it is known that they were from the right wing.

In the aftermath of Lieutenant José del Castillo's death, two witnesses present at the scene had conflicting accounts. One of them, who had been killed in a similar manner as Castillo, defiantly threw his cap at Director General of Security José Alonso Mallol. Despite this act of insubordination, Mallol did not take any disciplinary action and only requested calm. Castillo's wife, relatives, and officers of the Assault Guard, as well as socialist militia members, including those from "La Motorizada," where Castillo served as an instructor, attended his funeral chapel in the red room of the General Directorate of Security. Notable attendees from "La Motorizada" included Enrique Puente, Luis Cuenca, and Santiago Garcés, all of whom had experience with firearms and had provided protection to centrist socialist leader Indalecio Prieto.

The assassination of Lieutenant Castillo deeply shocked many, particularly his friend Luis Cuenca and fellow socialist militia members from "La Motorizada," including Enrique Puente and Santiago Garcés. That night, officers, non-commissioned officers, and guardsmen of Castillo, as well as civilians from socialist militias, gathered at the Pontejos barracks of the Assault Guard. Among them were José del Rey, a civil guard captain named Fernando Condés, and other close friends of Castillo. They were all outraged and demanded revenge for not only Castillo's murder but also other right-wing gunmen's attacks, such as the one on Captain Faraudo. The crowd grew emotional, with some expressing their frustration with the government for not taking action against these violent acts.

The assassination of Lieutenant Castillo led to outrage among his friends and fellow militia members, resulting in a gathering at the Pontejos barracks. Emotions ran high, with some expressing anger towards the government for not taking action against right-wing attacks. Barbeta, one of the attendees, addressed the crowd, vowing not to let Castillo's murder go unpunished, but later told the examining magistrate that he had gathered them to calm them down. Barbeta also instructed a corporal to select a group for a secret operation. Meanwhile, a group of Assault Guard officers, including Captain Moreno, met with the Interior Minister to demand immediate punishment for those responsible, whom they believed to be Phalanx gunmen. They obtained a list of Phalanx members suspected of involvement in the violence and planned to arrest them.

After Castillo's assassination, Assault Guard officers obtained a list of Phalanx members suspected of involvement in violence and planned to arrest them. With the help of a socialist militiaman, they added more names, including right-wing leaders Antonio Goicoechea, José María Gil-Robles, and José Calvo Sotelo, who had parliamentary immunity. Castillo's comrades, as per Gabriel Jackson, aimed to take dramatic revenge by assassinating a prominent right-wing leader, disregarding political parties or programs and the potential consequences.

Post-Castillo's assassination, Assault Guard officers, with the aid of a socialist militiaman (Manuel Tagüeña), prepared to arrest individuals linked to violence, expanding the list to include influential right-wing figures like Goicoechea, Gil-Robles, and Sotelo, who held parliamentary immunity. In the early hours, Lieutenant Alfredo León Lupión directed the vans from the Pontejos barracks, and socialist militiaman Tagüeña helped compile a list of high-profile Falangists to arrest. Around 1:30 AM, the driver of van number 17, Orencio Bayo Cambronero, was summoned for a task.

After Castillo's assassination, Assault Guard officers, with the help of a socialist militiaman named Tagüeña, prepared to arrest individuals associated with violence, expanding the list to include influential right-wing figures. At around 1:30 AM, the driver of van number 17, Orencio Bayo Cambronero, was summoned for a task. This group also included José del Rey Hernández, a guard with socialist ideas who had been assigned to escort the socialist deputy Margarita Nelken.

After Castillo's assassination, Assault Guard officers, with the help of a socialist militiaman named Tagüeña, prepared to arrest individuals associated with violence, expanding the list to include right-wing figures. After Castillo's assassination, a team of Assault Guards, socialist militiamen, and José del Rey Hernández prepared to arrest right-wing figures, with Fernando Condés, a Civil Guard officer, leading the way in an unusual situation. There are differing accounts of the group's route; some sources claim they tried to locate several individuals before going to Calvo Sotelo's house, while others state they went directly to his residence. It's worth noting that Condés' involvement in this mission was unconventional and questioned by some, like León Lupión, years later.

Following Castillo's assassination, a team consisting of Assault Guards, socialist militiamen, and José del Rey Hernández, led by Fernando Condés, a Civil Guard officer, planned to apprehend right-wing figures. Payne.

Two policemen, Antonio Oñate Escribano and Andrés Pérez Moler, were on night guard at the building entrance where Calvo Sotelo's house was located. The authors Alfonso Bullón de Mendoza and Ian Gibson have differing opinions on the group's stops before reaching Calvo Sotelo's home, with Gibson giving more weight to Santiago Garcés' testimony over that of the four arrested guards.

When the team led by Condés, which included Assault Guards, socialist militiamen, and José del Rey Hernández, arrived at Calvo Sotelo's residence to arrest him, they were allowed to pass by the two night guards, Antonio Oñate Escribano and Andrés Pérez Moler, after Condés presented his Civil Guard officer's card and they saw the group had arrived in an official car. At the time, Calvo Sotelo, his wife, their four children, the cook, the maid, the maid's fifteen-year-old brother, and the French governess were all in bed. The maid and cook initially refused to open the door, even after the group claimed to be policemen conducting a search and threatened to break down the door.

Upon arrival at Calvo Sotelo's home for his arrest, the team, consisting of several individuals in uniform and civilian clothes, had to convince the maid and cook to open the door. Once inside, they searched the premises and cut the telephone cord. Calvo Sotelo, awakened by the disturbance, confirmed the group's identity by checking with the night guards and observing the Assault Guards' van outside. After the search, Condés informed Calvo Sotelo of his arrest order, prompting the latter to question the action due to his parliamentary immunity.

Calvo Sotelo, upon being roused from sleep and informed of his arrest, expresses surprise and questions the action due to his parliamentary immunity and the inviolability of his home. He requests to call the General Director of Security, but is denied. His anxiety is only alleviated when Condés identifies himself as a Civil Guard officer. Calvo Sotelo reassures his worried wife, stating that he will return in an hour as he is a deputy and the government would not violate his immunity. He asks his wife to prepare a bag with clothes, a fountain pen, and paper. Despite his request, he is not permitted to dress in private.

Calvo Sotelo's wife pleads for him to stay, but he complies with the arrest and is denied privacy to dress. He bids farewell to his family, expecting to call his wife from the DGS, but acknowledging the possibility of being killed. He is described as a brave and strong individual, mentally prepared for martyrdom, and calm in the face of an unlawful search and potential murder. Speaking in French with the governess angers a guard, who orders him to switch to Spanish.

Calvo Sotelo asks the messenger to inform certain individuals of his arrest, but not his ill father. He bids farewell to the estate's doorman before being taken away in a van, where he is placed between two guards. Luis Cuenca, also in the van, fatally shoots him in the head, causing his body to slump between the seats. This event is a demonstration of Calvo Sotelo's bravery and mental preparation for potential harm, as described in the previous text.

Calvo Sotelo is killed in the van, and Captain Condés, upon hearing the gunshots, doesn't react except to direct the driver to the East cemetery. After Calvo Sotelo's disappearance, the Court of First Instance and Instruction No. 3 in Madrid took over the case, following notification from the Directorate General of Security (DGS). The court, led by Judge Ursicino Gómez Carbajo, initiated an investigation into the deputy's abduction, with the assistance of judicial secretary Pedro Pérez Alonso and authorized officer Emilio Macarrón. The DGS provided the court with the two guards who were on duty at Calvo Sotelo's residence. Judge Carbajo had previously been involved in the arrest of the Spanish Phalanx's Political Board and the investigation of Lieutenant Castillo's murder.

After receiving a second message from the DGS, Judge Ursicino Gómez Carbajo interrogates the two guards responsible for Calvo Sotelo's residence. Upon learning that the deputy's abduction was executed by a group of Assault Guards in an official van, led by a Civil Guard captain, the judge recognizes the gravity of the situation. He subsequently orders the temporary arrest of the guardsmen and begins a preliminary investigation.

After realizing the seriousness of Calvo Sotelo's abduction, Judge Gómez Carbajo arrests the guardsmen involved and starts a preliminary investigation. He criticizes the police's inaction and directs the First Criminal Brigade to bring the assault guards from the Pontejos barracks to court. The judge also orders the doorman and non-relative witnesses from Calvo Sotelo's estate to be presented at the court as part of the investigation. Gómez Carbajo aims to gather the guards and witnesses to promptly clarify the crime and present the perpetrators with evidence.

Upon returning to the court, Gómez Carbajo learns that the police have made no progress in identifying the murderers.
